newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Mitsui in 60 MW Sri Lanka power plant deal.
newsitem.headline: Mitsui in 60 MW Sri Lanka power plant deal.

text.p: Mitsui Engineering & Shipbuilding Company Ltd. of Japan signed an agreement with the Sri Lankan government on Thursday to build and operate a 60-megawatt barge-mounted power plant, the Board of Investment (BOI) said.
A letter of intent was signed by a Mitsui official and Sri Lankan government officials to construct the plant on a build, own, operate (BOO) basis, a BOI statement said.
It will be connected to the national grid through a sub station at Kotugoda in suburban Colombo, the statement said.

The letter of intent requires Mitsui to achieve several milestones, including compiling a detailed feasibility study, environmental clearance, commitment from financiers and signing a memorandum of understanding, within 180 days, it added.
Sri Lanka, which suffered crippling power cuts due to a drought last year, plans to reduce its dependence on rain-dependant hydroelectric power plants by increasing thermal electricity generation.

The Indian Ocean island's dependence on hydropower is expected to be slashed to 70 percent from 83 percent by next month when a 115-megawatt gas turbine and a 40- megawatt diesel plant are commissioned.
The state power utility Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) says it plans to further reduce hydropower to 57 percent of total capacity by building more thermal power plants.
The CEB also has plans to construct a 300 megawatt coal-fired power plant in the northwest, to be commissioned by the year 2000.
The island now has a permanent installed capacity of 1,135 megawatts of hydroelectric power and 250 megawatts of thermal power.
